entity_raw_name: II.	Independent Investigative Mechanism for Myanmar

content.text: A.	Proposed programme plan for 2026 and programme performance in 2024

children.text: Overall orientation
Mandates and background

8.II.1	The Independent Investigative Mechanism for Myanmar is mandated to collect, consolidate, preserve and analyse evidence of the most serious international crimes and violations of international law committed in Myanmar since 2011 and prepare files that can be shared with competent investigative, prosecutorial and judicial authorities (“competent authorities”) in order to facilitate fair and independent criminal proceedings in national, regional or international courts or tribunals. The mandate derives from Human Rights Council resolutions 39/2, 42/3, 43/26, 46/21, 47/1, 49/23, 50/3, 52/31, 53/26 and 56/1. In its resolution 43/26, the Council called for close and timely cooperation between the Mechanism and any future investigations by the International Criminal Court or the International Court of Justice. The mandate is further elaborated in the Mechanism’s terms of reference (A/73/716, annex).

8.II.2	The General Assembly welcomed the creation of the Mechanism in its resolution 73/264 and, in its resolutions 75/238, 76/180, 77/227, 78/219 and 79/182, called upon the United Nations to ensure that the Mechanism was afforded flexibility in terms of staffing, location and operational freedom so that it could deliver as effectively as possible on its mandate.
Programme of work
Objective

8.II.3	The objective, to which the Mechanism contributes, is to ensure accountability of perpetrators and justice for victims of the most serious international crimes and violations of international law committed in Myanmar since 2011.
Strategy and external factors for 2026
8.II.4	To contribute to the objective, the Mechanism will:
(a)	Collect and analyse information and evidence regarding crimes within its mandate, including by undertaking investigative missions;
(b)	Provide protection and support services to witnesses and information providers, including through cooperation with national authorities and other partners;

(c)	Develop and maintain a secure electronic information management system that can protect against evolving risks to information and communications technology security and facilitate the analysis of vast quantities of data in multiple formats and languages;
(d)	Share evidence and analysis with competent authorities in accordance with its mandate, including for proceedings at the International Criminal Court and the International Court of Justice;
(e)	Engage in outreach to relevant stakeholders, in particular to victims and witnesses, using various communication tools and civil society dialogues.
8.II.5	The above-mentioned work is expected to result in:
(a)	The collection and preservation of information and evidence that can be shared with competent authorities in relation to crimes within the Mechanism’s mandate;
(b)	The initiation of fair and independent criminal proceedings by competent authorities in relation to the aforementioned crimes;
(c)	Greater understanding of the Mechanism’s mandate, work and expected results by all relevant stakeholders, including victims and the general public, in particular inside Myanmar.
8.II.6	With regard to the external factors, the overall plan for 2026 is based on the following planning assumptions:

(a)	Some relevant Member States will permit the Mechanism to conduct evidence collection and witness interviews on their territory and facilitate the safety and well-being of witnesses and information providers;
(b)	Some competent authorities will seek to exercise jurisdiction over the crimes within the Mechanism’s mandate and such authorities will continue to request information from the Mechanism.

8.II.7	With regard to cooperation with other entities at the global, regional, national and local levels, the Mechanism continues to engage with Member States, individuals, civil society organizations and business entities to seek relevant information and ensure support for its mandate.

8.II.8	With regard to inter-agency coordination and liaison, the Mechanism continues to consult with international courts and other accountability mechanisms, in particular in the areas of legal and judicial cooperation, information management systems, investigation of sexual and gender-based crimes, witness protection and support, and development of methodologies and policies. The Mechanism also seeks the support of other United Nations entities working on issues relating to Myanmar to facilitate its activities.

8.II.9	The Mechanism integrates a gender perspective in its operational activities, deliverables and results, as appropriate. The Mechanism will continue its focus on sexual and gender-based crimes and crimes against children, including in the evidence and analysis it shares with competent authorities and through appropriate access to protection and support measures for victims of such crimes.

8.II.10	In line with the United Nations Disability Inclusion Strategy, the Mechanism will actively ensure appropriate access to protection and support measures to witnesses and victims with disabilities.
Evaluation activities

8.II.11	An evaluation conducted by the Mechanism on the establishment of cooperation arrangements with Member States for the purpose of facilitating the collection of testimonial and documentary evidence in their territory was completed in 2024 and has guided the proposed programme plan for 2026.

8.II.12	The evaluation affirmed the Mechanism’s progress in advancing numerous cooperation arrangements with a concrete impact on the Mechanism’s efforts, as reflected in results 1 and 3. In response to the results of the evaluation referenced above, the Mechanism will continue regular consultations with States and national authorities, including through regional networks; adopt pragmatic and flexible approaches to negotiating cooperation arrangements, including to encourage greater cooperation by States; and, as necessary, adopt alternative arrangements for collecting evidence. The evaluation will also inform efforts to improve efficiencies in the submission of requests to States to collect evidence in their territory and their consideration of such requests.
8.II.13	The following evaluations to be conducted by the Mechanism are planned for 2026:
(a)	Evaluation of the Mechanism’s methodology for sharing information with national authorities and related outcomes;
(b)	Evaluation of the Mechanism’s witness protection and support measures;
(c)	Evaluation of the Mechanism’s security systems and applications, including their impact.
Programme performance in 2024
National and international authorities utilize diverse formats of evidentiary material to advance ongoing legal proceedings

8.II.14	The Mechanism was established to enable national and international authorities to deliver justice for victims of serious international crimes committed in Myanmar. To that end, the Mechanism has been supporting three ongoing proceedings related to crimes committed against the Rohingya population in Myanmar that are being conducted by the International Court of Justice, the International Criminal Court and Federal Prosecutor’s Office No. 9 of Argentina. To date, the Mechanism has shared with competent authorities over 1 million information items in diverse formats, including witness statements, documents, photographs, videos, audio files, geospatial imagery, open-source materials and in-depth analytical products, on various matters of high contextual and evidentiary value to the ongoing proceedings. In September and November 2024 respectively, the Federal Prosecutor’s Office No. 9 of Argentina and the Office of the Prosecutor of the International Criminal Court made submissions to their respective judicial authorities seeking arrest warrants for certain individuals who are alleged to be responsible for serious international crimes committed against the Rohingya. The written submissions phase of the proceedings at the International Court of Justice regarding alleged violations by Myanmar of the Convention on the Prevention and Punishment of the Crime of Genocide concluded in late 2024 and oral hearings on the merits are expected to begin in 2025.
8.II.15	Progress towards the objective is presented in the performance measure below (see figure 8.II.I).
Figure 8.II.I
Performance measure: number of evidentiary materials accessed by competent authorities (annual)
Planned results for 2026
Result 1: domestic and international authorities have access to evidence that assists in establishing specific crimes and identifying perpetrators – Programme performance in 2024 and target for 2026

8.II.16	The Mechanism’s work contributed to domestic and international authorities having access to tailored, comprehensive and timely analytical products and underlying evidence in diverse formats that can assist such authorities in establishing specific crimes and identifying perpetrators of the most serious international crimes, which met the planned target.
8.II.17	Progress towards the objective and the target for 2026 are presented in the performance measure below (see table 8.II.1).
Table 8.II.1
Performance measure: domestic and international authorities have access to:

table_content.text: Repository and analysis of information and evidence regarding priority situations and incidents
Repository of evidence and targeted analysis of hate speech; military structures and chain of command; sexual and gender-based crimes; and two post-coup priority incidents in Kayah and Sagaing

Repository of evidence and targeted analysis, including of (a) financial structures and connections between persons and groups of interest; (b) three post-coup priority incidents in Sagaing; and (c) geolocation of sites of interest
Repository of evidence and analysis pertaining to key suspected individuals linked to priority situations and incidents
Repository of evidence and analysis pertaining to additional persons and groups of interest and priority situations and incidents, including in Rakhine State

children.text: Result 2: victims, survivors, civil society and information providers engage in accountability processes – Programme performance in 2024 and target for 2026

8.II.18	The Mechanism’s work contributed to 33 engagements with victims, survivors, civil society representatives and information providers, for a cumulative total of 130 engagements, which exceeded the planned target of 122 engagements.
8.II.19	Progress towards the objective and the target for 2026 are presented in the performance measure below (see figure 8.II.II).
Figure 8.II.II
Performance measure: number of engagements of victims, survivors, civil society representatives and information providers (cumulative)
Result 3: increased access to evidence with the broadest possible admissibility in national, regional and international courts – Proposed programme plan for 2026

8.II.20	Building complex international criminal cases requires forensically reliable and probative evidence. In accordance with best practices, the Mechanism has conducted screenings (preliminary interviews) and detailed interviews with victims and witnesses who have relevant information. The Mechanism has shared screening notes and witness statements with relevant competent authorities, contributing to progress in ongoing proceedings.
Lessons learned and planned change

8.II.21	The lesson for the Mechanism is that competent authorities have greatly valued the detailed witness statements that the Mechanism has taken in person from individuals with first-hand knowledge relevant to crimes. In applying the lesson, the Mechanism will continue to engage with more victims and individuals who witnessed the commission, planning or ordering of serious crimes to collect testimonies. In doing so, the Mechanism will continue to engage with individuals from a wide range of locations and backgrounds in an effort to increase the pool of witnesses in stable security situations who may be available to testify in judicial proceedings. Furthermore, the Mechanism will utilize more culturally informed interviewing techniques and focus the interviews on the core elements of crimes and evidence of the identity and responsibility of alleged perpetrators.
8.II.22	Expected progress towards the objective is presented in the performance measure below (see figure 8.II.III).
Figure 8.II.III
Performance measure: number of screening notes and witness statements available for sharing (cumulative)
Legislative mandates
8.II.23	The list below, which was reviewed in the preparation of the proposed programme budget, provides all mandates entrusted to the Mechanism.
General Assembly resolutions

table_content.text: Situation of human rights in Myanmar
Situation of human rights of Rohingya Muslims and other minorities in Myanmar

8.II.26	Additional details on the distribution of the proposed resources for 2026 are reflected in tables 8.II.6 to 8.II.8 and figure 8.II.IV.

8.II.27	As shown in tables 8.II.6 (1) and 8.II.7 (1), the overall resources proposed for 2026 amount to $15,834,600, reflecting a net increase of $180,800 (or 1.2 per cent) compared with the approved budget for 2025. Resource changes result from other changes. The proposed level of resources provides for the full, efficient and effective implementation of the Mechanism’s mandate.

Overall: evolution of financial resources by source of funding and component

children.text: Figure 8.II.IV
Distribution of proposed resources for 2026
(Number of positions/thousands of United States dollars)
Explanation of variances by factor
Other changes
8.II.28	As shown in tables 8.II.6 (1) and 8.II.7 (1), resource changes reflect an increase of $180,800, as follows:
(a)	An increase of $168,400 under other staff costs related to the proposed establishment of one position of Associate Field Security Coordination Officer (P-2) in Geneva (see annex II);

(b)	An increase of $10,100 related to the non-post provisions associated with the proposed establishment of the position of Associate Field Security Coordination Officer (P-2), comprising contractual services ($3,600), general operating expenses ($2,500) and furniture and equipment ($4,000);
(c)	An increase of $2,300 under contractual services relating to the higher standard price of the core software package for non-field personnel outside of Headquarters.
Extrabudgetary resources

8.II.29	As reflected in tables 8.II.6 (2) and 8.II.7 (2), extrabudgetary resources amount to $3,946,200. The resources would complement regular budget resources and would be used mainly to provide for 14 general temporary assistance positions (3 P-4, 5 P-3 and 6 P-2) to perform the functions of investigating sexual and gender-based crimes and crimes against and affecting children; financial and open-source investigations; information management; and programme management and administration. In addition, non-post resources would be used to cover the costs for information technology services, travel of staff, consultants, general operating expenses and specialized training required to implement the mandate.
8.II.30	The extrabudgetary resources under the Mechanism are subject to the oversight of the Mechanism, which has delegated authority from the Secretary-General.
Other information

8.II.31	In accordance with the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development, in particular target 12.6 of the Sustainable Development Goals, in which organizations are encouraged to integrate sustainability information into their reporting cycles, and in compliance with the cross-cutting mandate set out in paragraph 19 of General Assembly resolution 72/219, the Mechanism continues to minimize energy consumption at its facilities, where it installed special external walls with thermal insulation panels to reduce the dispersion of heat, thermal windows with energy-efficient features designed to resist the loss of heat and cold, light-emitting diode lights in all office and common areas, and a heating, ventilation and air-conditioning system with thermostats in all offices and common areas to enable better control of the system. The Mechanism also raises the awareness of its staff on energy-saving practices in the workplace.

8.II.32	Information on the timely submission of documentation and advance booking for air travel is reflected in table 8.II.9. The Mechanism will continue its efforts to improve the travel compliance rate through frequent monitoring of compliance with advance booking requirements for air travel, periodic briefings to staff on travel policies and monthly updates to managers.
Table 8.II.9
Compliance rate
(Percentage)

table_content.text: Air tickets purchased at least two weeks before the commencement of travel
